Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Recovery of Well Water Quality After the Great Louisiana 2016 Flood

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1661496 (Edwards).

Following a massive flood in Louisiana, this RAPID grant will help assist private well owners in the area assess and address the current safety of their potable water supply. Climate models predict that the frequency of flooding will increase in Louisiana and elsewhere in the U.S. The 47 million residents in the U.S. reliant on well water, half of which normally test positive for microbial contamination, would benefit from a better understanding of one-time disinfection protocols.

After natural disasters, residents need low-cost, effective remediation options to ensure safe, clean drinking water. Shock chlorination is the primary disinfection method for microbial contamination in wells, but evidence suggests that this approach may not be appropriate under all conditions, the actual disinfection effect may be short-lived or incomplete, and there may be short-term increases in metals such as lead. The recent flooding event in Louisiana offers a unique opportunity to characterize well water quality after a flood, evaluate both natural and enhanced recovery after treatments such as shock chlorination, and assess public health issues experienced by low-income well owners using compromised wells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Before a flooding event well users are encouraged to take precautionary measures to prevent contamination, but there is limited understanding about how to effectively do this. This research evaluated preparation, response, and recovery efforts targeted to private well users in flood-impacted communities in Louisiana, North Carolina, and Virginia.

 

Evaluation of water quality and recovery needs after flooding

After the Great Louisiana Flood of 2016, we conducted a citizen science campaign to characterize microbial contamination in private wells and evaluate preparation and recovery behaviors among well users. Total coliform and E. coli bacteria were evaluated to determine surface water contamination and presence of pathogens. Detection rates were low 10 weeks after the flooding. Interestingly, there was widespread detection of Legionella spp. and sporadic detection of L. pneumophila and N. fowleri gene markers. These pathogens were not associated with the presence of coliform bacteria, which raised concerns about drinking water quality for private well users after a flooding event.

There were deficiencies in the release of flood-specific information and resources for flood preparation and recovery. This delay may have impeded well users from appropriately preparing for and recovering from the flooding event. The major barriers to well stewardship were risk misperceptions prior to the flood and lack of knowledge about recovery behaviors after the flood. Well users wanted information on water testing laboratories, treatment systems, well maintenance, and water contaminants.

We reviewed well program support offered by local health departments in North Carolina in the aftermath Hurricane Matthew. Surveying local health departments, we observed that support for well users with older private wells varied substantially, resulting in many areas where well users did not have access to assistance or outreach materials. This is problematic due to the widespread well water and groundwater contamination in North Carolina and more frequent flooding events associated with severe storms such as Hurricanes Matthew, Florence, and Michael.

 

Review of emergency well water disinfection strategies

Well users in our studies expressed a need for well water treatment in the aftermath of flooding events. To assess the status of current recommendations, we reviewed state-level well disinfection outreach materials. State-developed emergency well disinfection protocols were found in 34 of the 50 states. There was no overall consistency among protocols and inclusion of key components for well disinfection. Only one protocol instructed residents to measure the chlorine residual with an at-home chlorine kit and only three recommended optimizing pH to ensure the appropriate disinfection residuals form. Moreover, the majority of protocols (63%) were missing 1-2 other key disinfection steps. This effort underscores the need for consistent messaging and dissemination of data-driven resources for well water recovery. Without evidence-based guidance and a discussion of conditions under which disinfection may be ineffective, residents may have a false sense of security about the safety of their drinking water supply after disinfection.

 

Impact of flooding on microbial communities in private wells

After Hurricane Matthew, two flooded and two non-flooded monitoring wells in the Potomac aquifer were monitored to evaluate changes in water quality. The influx of floodwater led to differences in the microbial populations and inorganic parameters. Total bacteria counts in the flooded wells were higher than the non-flooded wells, most likely supported by the organic matter that was introduced during the flooding. The most significant difference between the flooded and non-flooded wells was the presence of Erysipelothrix in flooded wells, which are bacteria associated with fecal contamination from pig farming activities. After purging three well volumes, water quality in flooded wells were comparable to non-flooded wells. This research illustrated that flushing a well shifted inorganic concentrations and relative abundance of bacteria, suggesting that this may be an important first well water recovery step.

 

Overall, this research advanced the understanding of the impact of flooding on private well communities and well recovery. Educational and professional development opportunities were provided to 16 graduate students and postdoctoral researchers at two universities. This collaborative research also fostered collaborative research projects with multiple local and state government agencies and provided testing and educational platforms and resources for both officials and residents. Research from this grant will result in 5 journal article submissions and has contributed to four graduate reports, theses, or dissertations. More importantly, we aim to make the results of this study available to emergency planners and flood responders, with the ultimate goal of improving disaster preparedness and recovery.
